meta.title: The Story Engine: An Entrepreneur's Guide to Content Strategy and Brand Storytelling Without Spending All Day Writing
meta.author: Kyle Gray

parts.title: Why Content Marketing with The Story Engine
parts.body: The introduction to *The Story Engine* shares Tom Morkes’ thoughts on content marketing as a powerful yet often overlooked tool. Many shy away because it’s hard to create captivating content and seeing returns takes time. However, Kyle Gray’s book offers a strategy to succeed in content marketing. Tom shares his journey, explaining that great content gains value over time, and introduces Kyle's experiences with WP Curve. The book provides a playbook to handle the challenges in content creation and helps turn it into a manageable process for business growth.

parts.title: The Invisible Value of Content Marketing
parts.body: Content marketing is unconventional in digital marketing. It contributes to brand building and relationship building beyond measurable outcomes like sales or conversions. This change in perspective emphasizes relationships over immediate ROI. Some results, like inspiring fans, recruiting talent, or attracting partners, can't be tracked traditionally but offer significant value. Patrick Hourihan notes content's role in a fluid, non-linear purchase cycle. Shifting to see content's broader impact encourages trust building and can lead to unexpected opportunities. Alex Turnbull from GrooveHQ highlights content's power in creating fans who advocate for the brand even if they're not direct customers. Dan Norris’s partnership formation for WP Curve illustrates content's role in collaboration. Success in content marketing isn't immediate but stems from a long-term relationship strategy.

parts.title: The Importance of a Well-Documented Content Strategy
parts.body: Having a content strategy gives your business an edge. Out of B2B marketers, 53% of the most effective have a documented strategy, compared to 40% of the least effective with no strategy. Without a written plan, your content direction may not align with your goals, similar to how a phone description of a landscape rarely matches the image in your mind when someone draws it. This highlights the importance of clearly writing down your strategy to ensure everyone is aligned and to improve it over time. Developing a well-documented strategy involves answering key questions about your content mission and target audience. For instance, your content should not just aim to get more customers but have a broader vision that resonates above sales. Using tools like empathy maps can help you understand what's happening in the minds of your audience. This understanding should guide your content creation, ensuring it aligns with the core problems your audience faces, which is crucial for long-term success.

parts.title: Building Influential Connections
parts.body: Relationships are crucial for early wins in content marketing. Networking with influencers can drive initial traffic to your site, so it's important to build these connections consistently. As campaigns progress, target more significant personalities and collaborations might come your way. Use a system to track interactions to avoid losing valuable connections amid distractions. Even for an extrovert, structure helps visualize and manage your network. Seek out influencers by asking current followers, using social media tools like Followerwonk and Littlebird, or exploring Facebook groups and podcasts to identify influential personalities.

parts.title: Image Optimization Essentials
parts.body: Images Large images can slow load times, hurt SEO, and affect reader experience. Always use images sized to fit their intended display size to avoid pixelation or blurring. Image formats: 1. JPEG: Best for photos. 2. PNG: Ideal for screenshots. 3. GIF: Great for animations. Size control is crucial for site speed, impacts search traffic, and hosting costs.

parts.title: Chapter 11 - Becoming a Content Idea Machine
parts.body:
Chapter 11 - Becoming a Content Idea Machine

Generating content ideas can be challenging initially, but it doesn’t have to be groundbreaking. Your customers might be unaware of other businesses' content. The key is consistency. Find a rhythm by batching idea generation. Experiment with drafting consistently, even if it feels less inspiring. Once writing becomes a habit, it gets easier. Remember, approaches to a topic can be varied. Try experimenting with different tones or angles. Focus on broad themes for extended periods, and observe what works for competitors.

parts.title: Enhancing Blog Engagement with Visual Content
parts.body: Visual content is crucial for creating a distinct look and feel for your blog, setting you apart from others. A unique art style adds personality in a way that content alone cannot. Blogs like "Wait But Why" use simple stick figure illustrations to effectively communicate ideas, despite their "low budget" appearance. The blog masterfully uses visual content to clarify ideas, add comic relief, and break up long posts, making it more engaging for readers. The use of recurring characters, like AdEspresso's blog mascot, creates consistency and makes the content relatable to followers. However, it's essential that visuals resonate with your audience, as the Empire Flippers learned when they had to eliminate cartoon visuals that damaged customer trust. Upon rebranding with a minimalist look, they experienced more growth, highlighting the importance of fitting visuals to audience expectations.

parts.title: Team Engagement in Content Marketing
parts.body: Involve your team in content marketing to make it more interesting and connect better with customers. By sharing stories and insights from multiple team members, you enhance content depth and make your brand more relatable. It's crucial to educate your team on the value of content marketing so they buy into the campaign. Share goals, case studies, and your vision to engage them. Encourage contribution by making it easy to share ideas through templates or regular brainstorm sessions. Build a knowledge base where team expertise is stored, offering valuable insights for content. Team-generated content, such as community posts or roundups, can highlight company culture and strengthen team involvement. Finally, ensure simple methods for the team to promote content via email notifications, enabling collective social media reach.

parts.title: Hiring and Collaborating with Writers
parts.body: Chapter 21 focuses on the importance of hiring writers to boost content creation without overwhelming entrepreneurs. Platforms like Problogger, Zerys, Upwork, and guest blogs are suggested for finding skilled writers. It's essential to find writers who are native speakers, have engagement in their prior work, and are capable of meeting deadlines. Bonus skills include SEO understanding, design, and social media strategies. When hiring writers, compensation should be agreed upon per article and vary based on industry standard and expertise. Writers should start with one article and can be assigned more work as trust builds. Pay rates generally range from $70-$350 for developed articles. Additional considerations like technical knowledge of a topic can influence pay.

parts.title: Onboarding and Managing Writers Effectively
parts.body: Make sure your writers have everything they need to do their job without too much back and forth. Walk them through the content strategy, style guide, keyword bank, and key relationships. Emphasize the importance of the style guide in their work and encourage questions and comments for clarity. Start new writers with well-defined tasks to minimize interpretation errors. As they become familiar with your system, gradually increase their freedom in research and topic selection. When proposing a blog post, provide a summary, and links to relevant content. Consider including an outline or abstract highlighting key points to cover.
